summary: This is the Executive Summary of a November 2020 report by the Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) investigating the conduct of federal prosecutors in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida regarding the 2007-2008 resolution of the federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. The report examines the negotiation and execution of a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Epstein and the office's interactions with victims, concluding that while the prosecutors did not commit professional misconduct, former U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta exercised poor judgment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Multi-millionaire financier investigated for illegal sexual activity with underage girls, who entered into a non-prosecution agreement with federal prosecutors in 2007.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney who made the pivotal decision to resolve the federal investigation of Epstein through a state-based plea and non-prosecution agreement; later served as U.S. Secretary of Labor.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.role: U.S. Senator, Chairman of Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Oversight
persons.context: Sent a letter to OPR in December 2018 requesting an investigation into possible misconduct by DOJ attorneys in the Epstein case following a Miami Herald report.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Nominated Alexander Acosta to be Secretary of Labor in 2017.

persons.name: Ron DeSantis
persons.context: Announced in August 2019 that he directed the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to open an investigation into the conduct of state authorities relating to Epstein.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.context: Author of the November 28, 2018 Miami Herald investigative report 'Perversion of Justice' that detailed the Epstein case and the NPA, leading to public outrage and scrutiny.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, approved the non-prosecution agreement that resolved the federal investigation into Epstein's crimes.
Epstein, through his team of prominent attorneys, negotiated with Acosta's office to secure the NPA and later sought to invalidate it through appeals to senior DOJ officials.
Senator Sasse requested an OPR investigation into the conduct of DOJ attorneys, including Acosta, following the Miami Herald report on the Epstein NPA.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation Begins
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department began investigating Jeffrey Epstein after parents of a 14-year-old girl complained he paid her for a massage.

events.title: State Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Epstein for felony solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: Draft Federal Indictment Prepared
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney submitted a draft 60-count federal indictment against Epstein to her supervisors.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida signed a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein, ending the federal investigation in exchange for a state guilty plea, incarceration, and sex offender registration.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein appeared in state court and pled guilty to state charges of felony solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors to engage in prostitution, as required by the NPA.

events.title: CVRA Lawsuit Filed
events.description: A victim, 'Jane Doe,' filed an emergency petition in federal court alleging the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by resolving the Epstein investigation without consulting victims.

events.title: Epstein Released to Home Detention
events.description: Epstein was released from custody to a one-year term of home detention after serving less than 13 months of an 18-month sentence due to 'gain time.'

events.title: Miami Herald Investigative Report Published
events.description: The Miami Herald published an extensive investigative report by Julie K. Brown detailing the Epstein case and the 'deal of a lifetime' NPA, leading to public outrage and renewed scrutiny.

events.title: Court Finds CVRA Violation
events.description: A federal district court granted victims' motion for partial summary judgment, ruling the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to advise victims about the NPA and misleading them.

events.title: Federal Indictment in New York
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York obtained a federal grand jury indictment charging Epstein with sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy.

events.title: Acosta's Press Conference
events.description: Acosta, then Secretary of Labor, held a televised press conference to defend his and the USAO's actions in the Epstein case.

events.title: Acosta Resigns
events.description: Acosta submitted his resignation as Secretary of Labor to President Trump.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan and was pronounced dead; the medical examiner concluded suicide.

locations: Florida Science Foundation, West Palm Beach
keyFacts: The DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility investigated federal prosecutors for their handling of the 2006-2008 Epstein investigation and concluded they did not commit professional misconduct, but that former U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta exercised poor judgment.

The non-prosecution agreement (NPA) signed on September 24, 2007, allowed Epstein to avoid federal prosecution by pleading guilty to state charges, serving incarceration, registering as a sex offender, and providing a mechanism for victim restitution.

Victims were not informed of or consulted about the NPA before it was signed, and the government was later found by a federal court to have violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to advise victims and misleading them about the status of the investigation.
Epstein served less than 13 months in a Palm Beach County jail (with work release) instead of the agreed 18 months due to 'gain time,' and was released to home detention in July 2009.

The November 2018 Miami Herald investigative report triggered public outrage, congressional scrutiny, and ultimately this OPR investigation, leading to renewed legal action and Epstein's 2019 federal indictment in New York.
